abstract.p: The netCDF Moving Features encoding extension is a summary of conventions that supports efficient exchange of simple moving features as binary files. This Best Practice is a complement to the Moving Features Encoding Part I: XML Core and an alternative to the Simple Comma Separated Values (CSV) extension. Compared to the CSV encoding, this netCDF encoding offers more compact storage and better performance at the cost of additional restrictions on the kinds of features that can be stored.

localized-strings.localized-string: Terms, definitions, symbols and abbreviated terms

localized-string.p: No terms and definitions are listed in this document.

This document uses the terms defined in OGC Policy Directive 49, which is based on the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2, Rules for the structure and drafting of International Standards. In particular, the word “shall” (not “must”) is the verb form used to indicate a requirement to be strictly followed to conform to this document and OGC documents do not use the equivalent phrases in the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2.

This document also uses terms defined in the OGC Standard for Modular specifications (OGC 08-131r3), also known as the 'ModSpec'. The definitions of terms such as standard, specification, requirement, and conformance test are provided in the ModSpec.
For the purposes of this document, the following additional terms and definitions apply.

localized-strings.localized-string: The following documents are referred to in the text in such a way that some or all of their content constitutes requirements of this document. For dated references, only the edition cited applies. For undated references, the latest edition of the referenced document (including any amendments) applies.
There are no normative references in this document.

For the purposes of this document, the terms and definitions given in % additionally apply.

In particular, the word “shall” (not “must”) is the verb form used to indicate a requirement to be strictly followed to conform to this document and OGC documents do not use the equivalent phrases in the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2.

This document also uses terms defined in the OGC Standard for Modular specifications (OGC 08-131r3), also known as the 'ModSpec'. The definitions of terms such as standard, specification, requirement, and conformance test are provided in the ModSpec.
For the purposes of this document, the terms and definitions given in % and the following additionally apply.

semantic__abstract.semantic__p: The netCDF Moving Features encoding extension is a summary of conventions that supports efficient exchange of simple moving features as binary files. This Best Practice is a complement to the Moving Features Encoding Part I: XML Core and an alternative to the Simple Comma Separated Values (CSV) extension. Compared to the CSV encoding, this netCDF encoding offers more compact storage and better performance at the cost of additional restrictions on the kinds of features that can be stored.

Recipients of this document are requested to submit, with their comments, notification of any relevant patent claims or other intellectual property rights of which they may be aware that might be infringed by any implementation of the standard set forth in this document, and to provide supporting documentation.
Use of this document is subject to the license agreement at

This document defines an OGC Best Practice on a particular technology or approach related to an OGC standard. This document is not an OGC Standard and may not be referred to as an OGC Standard. It is subject to change without notice. However, this document is an official position of the OGC membership on this particular technology topic.
Recipients of this document are invited to submit, with their comments, notification of any relevant patent rights of which they are aware and to provide supporting documentation.

semantic__abstract.semantic__p: The netCDF Moving Features encoding extension is a summary of conventions that supports efficient exchange of simple moving features as binary files. This Best Practice is a complement to the Moving Features Encoding Part I: XML Core and an alternative to the Simple Comma Separated Values (CSV) extension. Compared to the CSV encoding, this netCDF encoding offers more compact storage and better performance at the cost of additional restrictions on the kinds of features that can be stored.

semantic__foreword.semantic__p: This document does not define any new Moving Features elements, rather it provides a method to encode discrete sampling geometries as netCDF files. This Best Practice combines two existing OGC specifications:

semantic__li.semantic__p: The Network Common Data Form (netCDF) standard [OGC 10-092r3], which provides the binary encoding of array-oriented scientific data; and
A subset of the Climate and Forecast (CF) conventions [OGC 11-165r2], which provides standard names and layout for the arrays to encode in a netCDF file.

semantic__foreword.semantic__p: This encoding is intended to provide a faster and more compact alternative to the Moving Features CSV encoding using a format readable by existing software.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The OGC 11-165r2 CF-netCDF standard is based on Climate and Forecast (CF) conventions version 1.6. The Attribute Convention for Data Discovery (ACDD) adds additional attributes that provide useful metadata for Catalog Service on the Web (CSW). The National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI) document is used as a guideline when an ambiguity needs to be resolved.

This document references OGC 11-165r2 when possible, but the on-line CF, ACDD, or NCEI documents may be referenced when additional information is considered relevant to moving feature binary encoding.
No security considerations have been made for this document.

semantic__submitters.semantic__p: All questions regarding this submission should be directed to the editor or the submitters:

semantic__clause.semantic__p: This OGC® Best Practice gives guidelines for encoding in netCDF files the geometries of features that move as rigid bodies. This is an alternative to the encoding defined by the OGC Moving Features Encoding Extension: Simple Comma Separated Values (CSV) standard. netCDF encoding can store moving features with the following characteristics:

semantic__li.semantic__p: Each moving feature can be described with the Schema for Moving Features (ISO 19141:2008);
The number of features simultaneously encoded with this format can be massive (many thousands of features);
All features can be described using common space-time coordinates;
Trajectories are described by a single point (not a line string) at each time step;
Foliation order is sequential, i.e., trajectory elements that are parts of one track are ordered by time.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: Deforming features such as floodwater and geometric complexes are out of scope.

This OGC document describes relevant attributes from the Climate and Forecast (CF) conventions in sufficient detail that client applications do not need to deal with the entire scope of CF conventions. Applications only need to understand a restricted subset of CF conventions in order to be able to interpret moving features in netCDF files.
Conformance with this specification shall be checked using all the relevant tests specified in Annex A (normative).

semantic__terms.semantic__p: This document uses the terms defined in OGC Policy Directive 49, which is based on the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2, Rules for the structure and drafting of International Standards. In particular, the word “shall” (not “must”) is the verb form used to indicate a requirement to be strictly followed to conform to this document and OGC documents do not use the equivalent phrases in the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2.

This document also uses terms defined in the OGC Standard for Modular specifications (OGC 08-131r3), also known as the ‘ModSpec’. The definitions of terms such as standard, specification, requirement, and conformance test are provided in the ModSpec.
For the purposes of this document, the following additional terms and definitions apply.

This document uses the terms defined in Sub-clause 5.3 of OGC 06-121r8, which is based on the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2, Rules for the structure and drafting of International Standards. In particular, the word “shall” (not “must”) is the verb form used to indicate a requirement to be strictly followed to conform to this standard.

semantic__verbal-definition.semantic__p: Representation, using a local origin and local ordinate vectors, of a geometric object at a given reference time.
Quantity having direction as well as magnitude.
Spatial object representing a geometric set.
Geometric object representing a single, connected, homogeneous element of space.
1-dimensional geometric primitive representing extent in time.
0-dimensional geometric primitive representing a position in time.
Path of a moving point described by a one parameter set of points.
One parameter set of geometries such that each point in the prism of the set is in one and only one trajectory and in one and only one leaf.

Function

t ∈

P ∈ f

P in f(a) there is a one parameter set of points (called the trajectory of

P(t) in f(t).
Set of points in the union of the geometries (or the union of the trajectories) of a one parameter set of geometries.
Geometry at a particular value of the parameter.
NetCDF attributes hold metadata. An attribute contains information about properties of a variable or an entire dataset.
Global attributes apply to a whole dataset and may be used to record properties of all the data in a file, such as processing history or conventions used.
Variable attributes record the properties of one variable.

A netCDF variable has a name, type, shape, attributes, and values. In face, much of the netCDF specification consists of defining the specific characteristics of variables. Variables hold data values. In the netCDF model, a variable can hold a multidimensional array of values of the same type.
The shape of a variable is specified with a list of zero or more dimensions.
NetCDF dimensions are used to specify variable shapes, common grids, and coordinate systems.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: This section provides details and examples for conventions used in the document.

semantic__definitions.semantic__p: The following symbols and abbreviated terms are used in this Best Practice:

semantic__dd.semantic__p: International Association of Oil & Gas producers
NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information

semantic__clause.semantic__p:
The data model used by the binary encoding is equivalent to that used by the CSV encoding. shows an example for trajectories of three moving points
A
A,
B
B and
C
C. Each trajectory has the same start time and the same end time.

semantic__li.semantic__p:
At
t = 0
t = 0 (start of all data), all points start moving.

At
t = 1
t = 1, the movement of
A
A is changed.

At
t = 2
t = 2 (end of all data), the movement of
A
A,
B
B and
C
C are changed.

semantic__clause.semantic__p:
In the case, the trajectory of
A
A from
t = 0
t = 0 to
t = 1
t = 1 and from
t = 1
t = 1 to
t = 2
t = 2 is encoded, together with the trajectories of
B
B and
C
C from
t = 0
t = 0 to
t = 2
t = 2.

The binary encoding of arrays and attributes is defined by OGC 10-092r3 – NetCDF Binary Encoding Extension Standard: netCDF Classic and 64-bit Offset Format. That netCDF standard defines only a “container” format – it does not define the meaning of attributes stored in the file (the “schema” in XML terminology).
The full content of OGC 10-092r3 standard is needed for Moving Feature Simple Binary; this Best Practice does not propose any addition or subset of OGC 10-092r3.

semantic__tr.semantic__td: All Moving Features binary files shall be compliant with the netCDF binary encoding as specified by the OGC 10-092r3 standard.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: Meanings of attributes in a netCDF file are defined by a separated standard, OGC 11-165r2 – CF-netCDF3 Data Model Extension. All remaining requirements and recommendations in this Moving Feature Simple Binary document apply to a subset of those CF conventions.

Global attributes apply to the netCDF file as a whole. They specify a succinct description of what is in the dataset, the kind of sampling geometry, the geographic bounding box, the vertical extent, the time period, the coordinate reference systems used and many other metadata (see CF convention). Some global attributes are merely a convenience for information that may otherwise be tedious to compute; those attributes are presented in .
This sub-section presents some global attributes that do not duplicate information provided by other attributes.

To identify that the file uses the CF convention, OGC 11-162r2 §7.3.2.1 requires that the Conventions global attribute is set to the "CF-1.6" string value. This Best Practice uses also some attribute convention for data discovery, which is notified by the "ACDD-1.3" string value.

semantic__tr.semantic__td: The file shall define the global attribute Conventions to a string of comma-separated values containing at least the "CF-1.6" element. The list of values should contain also the "ACDD-1.3" element. A complete string value containing the two elements is "CF-1.6, ACDD-1.3".

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The CF conventions allow different kinds of sampling geometry such as point, time series, profile, or trajectory. This binary encoding Best Practice focuses on trajectories. This choice constraint the data layout to a series of data points along a path through space with monotonically increasing times (OGC 11-165r2 §7.5.2.3).

semantic__tr.semantic__td: The file shall define the global attribute featureType to the string value "trajectory".

semantic__clause.semantic__p: Both CF convention and ACDD recommend the inclusion of a title in the global attributes.

semantic__tr.semantic__td: The file should define the global attribute title to a succinct description of what is in the dataset.

semantic__clause.semantic__title: Convenience global attributes for data discovery
semantic__clause.semantic__p: This sub-section presents global attributes that duplicate information available in other attributes, but in a more convenient manner. For example, the geographic bounding box attributes () duplicate information provided by the geospatial bounds attributes ( to ), but may avoid the need to apply an inverse map projection. The geospatial bounds attributes themselves duplicate attributes associated to coordinate variables. But the attributes described in this sub-section make it easier to discover the data. Indeed, all attributes in this sub-section come from the Attribute Convention for Data Discovery (ACDD). By contrast, most attributes in other sections come from the Climate and Forecast (CF) convention.

The geographic bounding box is given in longitude and latitude regardless of the Coordinate Reference System (CRS) used by the trajectories. Since those metadata are used for discovery purpose only, the geodetic datum is unspecified. Coordinate precision may be of only two decimal places of a degree.

semantic__td.semantic__p: The file should define the following global attributes:

Respective values are the southernmost and northernmost latitudes, followed by the easternmost and westernmost longitudes covered by the dataset. Units of measurement should be degrees with positive latitudes in the North hemisphere and longitude values increasing toward east. The “minimal” longitude may be greater than the “maximal” longitude if the bounding box crosses the discontinuity meridian. The Prime Meridian should be Greenwich. Values type should be floating point.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: This geographic bounding box is redundant with the geospatial bounds defined below. The geographic bounding box is optional metadata for easier discovery of a dataset without the need to parse Well Known Text, lookup EPSG codes, and reproject envelopes.
The horizontal part of the spatial boundary of moving features is specified as geometry in Well Known Text (WKT) format. The Coordinate Reference System is specified in .

This metadata is equivalent to the mf:STBoundedBy element defined by Moving Features Core and to the @stboundedby element defined by the CSV extension, except that the geometry is not an envelope (but may be an equivalent polygon) and does not contain vertical or temporal components.

semantic__tr.semantic__td: The file should define the global attribute geospatial_bounds to a Well Known Text (WKT) that specifies the horizontal part of a geometry encompassing all moving features in the dataset. The geometry may be a polygon. Meaning and order of values for each point’s coordinates depend on the Coordinate Reference System ().

semantic__clause.semantic__p: If the feature trajectories are three-dimensional, then the vertical part of the spatial boundary of moving features is specified as a range of floating-point values. The Coordinate Reference System is specified in .
This metadata is equivalent to the vertical component of mf:STBoundedBy (Moving Features Core) or @stboundedby (CSV extension).

semantic__tr.semantic__td: If the moving features feature trajectories are three-dimensional, then the file should define the global attribute geospatial_vertical_min and geospatial_vertical_max to the numerically smaller and larger vertical limit, respectively. Values type should be floating point. Meaning of values depends on the Coordinate Reference System ().

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The times of the first and last data point in the file are specified as a range of dates. Dates are formatted as specified by ISO 8601:2004, preferably the extended date-time format (YYYY-MM-DD T hh:mm:ss optionally followed by the time zone).

semantic__tr.semantic__td: The file should define the global attribute time_coverage_start to the time of the first data point, and time_coverage_end to the time of the last data point. Dates are encoded as strings in ISO 8701:2004 format.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The Coordinate Reference System (CRS) of the geospatial and vertical bounds ( and ) is specified by an authority code, preferably from the EPSG geodetic dataset. For two-dimensional trajectories, only one CRS should be specified. For three-dimensional trajectories, a single three-dimensional CRS or two distinct CRS (one horizontal and one vertical) may be specified depending on the nature of the vertical heights.

While ACDD uses simple strings of the form "EPSG:4326", this document recommends URNs of the form "urn:ogc:def:crs:EPSG::4326" instead. However, software should be prepared to read both forms. Note that axis order is the same with both forms, namely (latitude, longitude) in EPSG:4326 case.
This metadata is equivalent to the srsName attribute in Moving Feature core and to the srid attribute in CSV extension, except for the possible separation between a horizontal and a vertical CRS.

semantic__td.semantic__p: The file should define the global attribute geospatial_bounds_crs and may define the global attribute geospatial_bounds_vertical_crs to authority codes (preferable from the EPSG geodetic dataset) determined according the following choices:

semantic__li.semantic__p: If the trajectories are three-dimensional and horizontal coordinates are geodetic (geographic or geocentric) latitudes and longitudes and the vertical coordinates are heights above the ellipsoid, then:
geospatial_bounds_vertical_crs attribute is not present.

geospatial_bounds_crs is the authority code of a single three-dimensional geodetic CRS used by both geospatial_bounds (for the horizontal part) and by geospatial_vertical_min and geospatial_vertical_max (for the vertical part) attribute values. For example EPSG:4979 is the three-dimensional variant of EPSG:4326.
Otherwise:
geospatial_bounds_crs is the authority code of the two-dimensional CRS used by the geospatial_bounds attribute value.
geospatial_bounds_vertical_crs is the authority code of the CRS used by geospatial_vertical_min and geospatial_vertical_max, if present.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The CF convention proposes four different ways to organize the feature coordinates and attributes in a netCDF file. This best-practice paper chooses the Contiguous Ragged Array representation, which has the following characteristics:

semantic__li.semantic__p: Can mix short and large features without waste of space;
Number of points of each feature must be known in advance;
File can be updated with new features or new points in the last feature (but not new points in previous features); and
Foliation order is restricted to “sequential”.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The file is organized by first defining netCDF dimensions (not to be confused with spatio-temporal dimensions), then variables. The dimension and variable names shall comply with the restrictions documented in OGC 11-162r2 §7.3.2.1:

semantic__td.semantic__p: NetCDF dimension names and netCDF variable names shall comply with the following restrictions:

semantic__li.semantic__p: Names shall begin with a letter;
Names shall be composed of letters, digits or underscores; and
No variable has the same name than a dimension, except the variable holding feature identifiers ().

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The ragged array representation needs three netCDF dimensions, described below.

If each feature is identified by a string value, then the netCDF file needs to declare the maximal number of characters allowed in those identifiers. Identifiers shorter than the maximal length will be padded by spaces of null characters (readers must be prepared to handle both).

semantic__tr.semantic__td: If features are identified by string values, then the file shall define a netCDF dimension for identifier characters (the identifier char dimension). The name of this dimension can be any name compliant with the requirements in . The length of this dimension is the maximum number of characters than can be stored in a feature identifier.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The netCDF file shall declare a dimension for information about each feature as a whole (i.e., information that does not depend on the time). The length of this dimension is the maximal number of features that can be stored in the file. It is acceptable to declare a length larger than needed in order to reserve room for future feature additions, provided that values in the count variable () are set to zero for all missing features.

semantic__tr.semantic__td: The file shall define a netCDF dimension for feature instances (the instance dimension). The name of this dimension can be any name compliant with the requirements in . The length of this dimension is the maximum number of features that can be stored in the file.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The netCF file shall declare a dimension for the actual data (time, geospatial coordinates and feature attributes). This dimension could have a fixed length, but it is more convenient to declare this dimension length as unlimited if new data need to be appended. Note that a netCDF file can have only one dimension of unlimited length.

semantic__tr.semantic__td: The file shall define a netCDF dimension for time-dependent data (the sample dimension). The name of this dimension can be any name compliant with the requirements in . The length of this dimension should be unlimited, unless the total number of points is known in advance.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: In the continuous ragged array representation, the netCDF file shall contain the following variables:

semantic__li.semantic__p: One variable listing feature identifiers;
One variable counting the number of points in each feature;

Three or four auxiliary coordinate variables (not to be confused with “simple” coordinate variables): examples:
x
x,
y
y, (
z
z) and
t
t; and
An arbitrary number of variables for feature attributes (not to be confused with global attributes or variable attributes): examples: state, temperature.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: Each trajectory should have identifying text that specifies the moving feature. The text can be a person ID, a vehicle ID, etc. While the identifier is usually a string, integer types are also allowed.
The data stored in this variable are equivalent to the mfIdRef attribute value in Moving Feature XML file, or to the values in the mfidref column in a Moving Feature CSV file.

semantic__td.semantic__p: The file shall define a variable holding the identifier of each trajectory.

semantic__li.semantic__p: The variable name shall be identical to the name of the instance dimension defined in .
The variable type should be the character type. Integer types are also valid.
The variable dimension shall be the instance dimension () and the identifier char dimension (), in that order. The char dimension shall be omitted if the variable type is not a character type.
The collection of variable attributes shall contain:
A cf_role attribute set to the "trajectory_id" string value.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The netCDF file shall contain a variable holding the number of points in each trajectory. The length of this variable is the maximum number of features that the netCDF file can contain.

semantic__td.semantic__p: The file shall define a variable holding the count of the number of points in each trajectory (the count variable).

semantic__li.semantic__p: The variable name can be any name compliant with the requirements in .
The variable type shall be an integer.
The variable dimension shall be the instance dimension defined in .
The collection of variable attributes shall contain:
A sample_dimension attribute set to the name of the sample dimension defined in .

semantic__clause.semantic__p: Trajectory coordinates are specified in one variable for each spatiotemporal dimension. Those “auxiliary coordinate variables” are not subject to the usual restrictions of netCDF “coordinate variables”. In particular:

semantic__li.semantic__p: The variable name does not match the dimension name;
The values do not need to be ordered monotonically;
The variable does not have axis attribute; and
The variable may have missing values.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: Ordinate values of the first feature – i.e., the feature at index 0 in the feature instance dimension () – are written first. The number of values to write for that first feature is given by the value of the count variable () at index 0. Then the ordinate values of the second feature – i.e., the feature at index 1 in the feature instance dimension – follow. The number of values to write for that second feature is given by the value of the count variable at index 1, and so on.
For example, if a file contains three features identified as “A”, “B” and “C” and if their trajectories are described by the following points:

semantic__li.semantic__p: A: start at (11, 2) then move to (12, 3) and finally (10, 3);
B: start at (10, 2) then move to (11, 3); and
C: start at (12, 1) then move to (10, 2) and finally (11, 3).

semantic__clause.semantic__p: Then the feature instance dimension has a length of 3 and the sample dimension (if not unlimited) has a length of 3 + 2 + 3 = 8. In such cases the variables presented in previous sub-sections have the following values:
NetCDF variables having the feature instance dimension ():
The auxiliary coordinate variables can be as below:
NetCDF variables having the sample dimension ():

semantic__td.semantic__p: The file shall contain three or four auxiliary coordinate variables.

semantic__li.semantic__p: The variable name can be any name compliant with the requirements in .
The variable type shall be a numerical type (usually floating point).
The variable dimension shall be the sample dimension defined in .
The collection of attributes of the time coordinates variable shall contain:
A standard_name attribute set to the "time" string value.
A units attribute set to the “units since YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss” string value where:
“units” can be “days”, “hours”, “minutes” or “seconds”,
“YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss” is the epoch in UTC.
The collection of attributes of spatial coordinates variables shall contain:
A standard_name attribute if and only if a standard name exists in the CF Standard Name Table ( ) for that variable. Examples of standard names are "longitude", "latitude" and "altitude".
A units attribute. Examples are "degrees_east", "degrees_north" and "km".
The collection of attributes of all coordinates variable shall contain:
An axis attribute with one of the following names: "X", "Y", "Z" or "T".

semantic__clause.semantic__p: In addition to the attributes listed in above requirement, some non-standards attributes may help parsers to identify the coordinate system. In particular, the _CoordinateAxisType attribute may be set to "Lon", "Lat", "Height" or "Time" values for a geographic CRS, or to the "GeoX", "GeoY", "GeoZ" or "Time" values for other kind of CRS.

If the file contains additional attributes for the moving features, they can be declared in array having the same length than the auxiliary coordinate variables. Elements in those variables are mapped to features and time in the same way than the values in auxiliary coordinate variables ().

semantic__tr.semantic__td:
If the file contains additional feature attributes, then those values shall be stored in one distinct variable for each feature attribute. The dimension of those variables is the sample dimension. Values at index
i
i are associated to the same feature at the same time than the values of auxiliary coordinate variables at index
i
i.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: OGC 11-162r2 has additional requirements for the exchange of scientific data.

semantic__tr.semantic__td: If the variable represents one of the physical quantities for which a standard name exists in the CF Standard Name Table ( ), then the variable shall define a standard_name attribute to the string value given in that table. Otherwise the variable shall define a long_name attribute to a long descriptive name that may, for example, be used for labeling plots.

If the variable represents a dimensional quantity, then it shall define a units attribute to a string value that can be recognized by UNIDATA’s udunits package, with the addition of "level", "layer" and "sigma_level" string values. That unit shall be consistent with the unit given in the CF Standard Name Table for the standard_name attribute value, if the later attribute exists for this variable.

semantic__clause.semantic__title: Feature attribute variables as character strings
semantic__clause.semantic__p: If the values of a feature attribute variable are character strings, then there is a choice:

semantic__li.semantic__p: If only a limited amount of distinct values are used (e.g., values are members of an enumeration), then those values can be encoded as flags as described in CF conventions §3.5 (details below);

Otherwise a new dimension need to be defined with a length equal to the maximal number of characters to be stored in the feature attribute variable. This dimension is added as the last dimensions of the feature attribute variable, as defined in CF-convention §2.2. This dimension is shown as the “character dimension” in the figure below.

semantic__clause.semantic__p: The second approach may result in a netCDF file as big as or bigger than an equivalent CSV file since all character strings shorter than the maximal length are padded with spaces or zero values. For efficiency reasons, this paper recommends the use of flags.

semantic__td.semantic__p: Feature attribute variables of type character strings should be encoded as flags if the amount of distinct values is reasonably small.

semantic__li.semantic__p: Variable type should be byte or short.
The collection of variable attributes should contain:
A flag_values attribute of the same type (byte or short) than the variable. The attribute value is the list of distinct numerical values that can appear in the variable.

A flag_meanings attribute of the type string. The attribute value is a space-separated list of tokens (a token is a word or a phrase in which space characters have been replaced by underscore characters). The first token is the string representation of the first numerical value listed in the flag_values array, the second token is the string representation of the second numerical value listed in the flag_values array, etc.

semantic__annex.semantic__p: Moving Features encoded in a netCDF file may be tested with the UCAR library, for example using the Java code below (replace “myFile.nc” and “myAttribute” by character strings applicable to the data to be tested). As of version 4.6.4 of UCAR netCDF library, this test requires the non-standard _CoordinateAxisType attribute on the auxiliary coordinate variables (see the note after requirement 10). For that reason, this test is non-normative.

semantic__references.semantic__p: The following documents are referred to in the text in such a way that some or all of their content constitutes requirements of this document. For dated references, only the edition cited applies. For undated references, the latest edition of the referenced document (including any amendments) applies.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: OGC® Moving Features Encoding Part I: XML Core
OGC® Moving Features Encoding Part I: XML Core
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: This OGC® Standard specifies standard encoding representations of movement of geographic features. The primary use case is information exchange.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: OGC® Moving Features Encoding Extension: Simple Comma Separated Values (CSV)
OGC® Moving Features Encoding Extension: Simple Comma Separated Values (CSV)
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: This OGC® Standard specifies standard encoding representations of movement of geographic features. The primary use case is information exchange.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: OGC Network Common Data Form (NetCDF) Core Encoding Standard version 1.0
OGC Network Common Data Form (NetCDF) Core Encoding Standard version 1.0
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: This document specifies the network Common Data Form (netCDF) core standard and extension mechanisms. The OGC netCDF encoding supports electronic encoding of geospatial data, specifically digital geospatial information representing space and time-varying phenomena. NetCDF is a data model for array-oriented scientific data. A freely distributed collection of access libraries implementing support for that data model, and a machine-independent format are available. Together, the interfaces, libraries, and format support the crea-tion, access, and sharing of multi-dimensional scientific data.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: NetCDF Binary Encoding Extension Standard: NetCDF Classic and 64-bit Offset Format
NetCDF Binary Encoding Extension Standard: NetCDF Classic and 64-bit Offset Format
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: This document defines an OGC® Standard for encoding binary representations of space-time varying geo-referenced data. Specifically, this standard specifies the netCDF classic and 64-bit offset file binary encoding formats. This standard specifies a set of requirements that every netCDF classic or 64-bit offset binary encoding must fulfil.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: CF-netCDF3 Data Model Extension standard
CF-netCDF3 Data Model Extension standard
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: The OGC netCDF encoding supports electronic encoding of geospatial data, that is, digital geospatial information representing space and time-varying phenomena. This standard specifies the CF-netCDF data model extension. This standard specifies the CF-netCDF data model mapping onto the ISO 19123 coverage schema. This standard deals with multi-dimensional gridded data and multi-dimensional multi-point data. In particular, this extension standard encoding profile is limited to multi-point, and regular and warped grids; however, irregular grids are important in the CF-netCDF community and work is underway to expand the CF-netCDF to encompass other coverages types, including irregular gridded datasets.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Geographic information
Reference model
Part 1: Fundamentals
Geographic information — Reference model — Part 1: Fundamentals
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: ISO 19101-1:2014 defines the reference model for standardization in the field of geographic information. This reference model describes the notion of interoperability and sets forth the fundamentals by which this standardization takes place. Although structured in the context of information technology and information technology standards, ISO 19101-1:2014 is independent of any application development method or technology implementation approach.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Geographic information
Schema for moving features
Geographic information — Schema for moving features
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: ISO 19141:2008 defines a method to describe the geometry of a feature that moves as a rigid body. Such movement has the following characteristics. — The feature moves within any domain composed of spatial objects as specified in ISO 19107. — The feature may move along a planned route, but it may deviate from the planned route. — Motion may be influenced by physical forces, such as orbital, gravitational, or inertial forces. — Motion of a feature may influence or be influenced by other features, for example: The moving feature might follow a predefined route (e.g. road), perhaps part of a network, and might change routes at known points (e.g. bus stops, waypoints). Two or more moving features may be “pulled” together or pushed apart (e.g. an airplane will be refuelled during flight, a predator detects and tracks a prey, refugee groups join forces). Two or more moving features may be constrained to maintain a given spatial relationship for some period (e.g. tractor and trailer, convoy). ISO 19141:2008 does not address other types of change to the feature. Examples of changes that are not adressed include the following: — The deformation of features. — The succession of either features or their associations. — The change of non-spatial attributes of features. — The feature’s geometric representation cannot be embedded in a geometric complex that contains the geometric representations of other features, since this would require the other features’ representations to be updated as the feature moves. Because ISO 19141:2008 is concerned with the geometric description of feature movement, it does not specify a mechanism for describing feature motion in terms of geographic identifiers. This is done, in part, in ISO 19133.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Geographic information
Spatial schema
Geographic information — Spatial schema
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: ISO 19107:2003 specifies conceptual schemas for describing the spatial characteristics of geographic features, and a set of spatial operations consistent with these schemas. It treats vector geometry and topology up to three dimensions. It defines standard spatial operations for use in access, query, management, processing, and data exchange of geographic information for spatial (geometric and topological) objects of up to three topological dimensions embedded in coordinate spaces of up to three axes.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__title: Geographic information
Schema for coverage geometry and functions
Geographic information — Schema for coverage geometry and functions
semantic__bibitem.semantic__abstract: ISO 19123:2005 defines a conceptual schema for the spatial characteristics of coverages. Coverages support mapping from a spatial, temporal or spatiotemporal domain to feature attribute values where feature attribute types are common to all geographic positions within the domain. A coverage domain consists of a collection of direct positions in a coordinate space that may be defined in terms of up to three spatial dimensions as well as a temporal dimension. Examples of coverages include rasters, triangulated irregular networks, point coverages and polygon coverages. Coverages are the prevailing data structures in a number of application areas, such as remote sensing, meteorology and mapping of bathymetry, elevation, soil and vegetation. ISO 19123:2005 defines the relationship between the domain of a coverage and an associated attribute range. The characteristics of the spatial domain are defined whereas the characteristics of the attribute range are not part of ISO 19123:2005.

semantic__bibitem.semantic__formattedref: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory: NetCDF CF Metadata Conventions.
ESIP: Attribute Convention for Data Discovery (ACDD).

clause.title: Copyright notice
clause.p:
Copyright © 2024 Open Geospatial Consortium
To obtain additional rights of use, visit

clause.title: Note
clause.p: Attention is drawn to the possibility that some of the elements of this document may be the subject of patent rights. The Open Geospatial Consortium shall not be held responsible for identifying any or all such patent rights.

Recipients of this document are requested to submit, with their comments, notification of any relevant patent claims or other intellectual property rights of which they may be aware that might be infringed by any implementation of the standard set forth in this document, and to provide supporting documentation.

clause.title: License Agreement
clause.p: Use of this document is subject to the license agreement at

clause.title: Notice
clause.p: This document defines an OGC Best Practice on a particular technology or approach related to an OGC standard. This document is not an OGC Standard and may not be referred to as an OGC Standard. It is subject to change without notice. However, this document is an official position of the OGC membership on this particular technology topic.
Recipients of this document are invited to submit, with their comments, notification of any relevant patent rights of which they are aware and to provide supporting documentation.

abstract.title: I.Abstract
abstract.p: The netCDF Moving Features encoding extension is a summary of conventions that supports efficient exchange of simple moving features as binary files. This Best Practice is a complement to the Moving Features Encoding Part I: XML Core and an alternative to the Simple Comma Separated Values (CSV) extension. Compared to the CSV encoding, this netCDF encoding offers more compact storage and better performance at the cost of additional restrictions on the kinds of features that can be stored.

clause.title: II.Keywords
clause.p: The following are keywords to be used by search engines and document catalogues.
ogcdoc, OGC document, Best Practice, moving features, netCDF, CF convention, trajectory

foreword.title: III.Preface
foreword.p: This document does not define any new Moving Features elements, rather it provides a method to encode discrete sampling geometries as netCDF files. This Best Practice combines two existing OGC specifications:

li.p: The Network Common Data Form (netCDF) standard [OGC 10-092r3], which provides the binary encoding of array-oriented scientific data; and
A subset of the Climate and Forecast (CF) conventions [OGC 11-165r2], which provides standard names and layout for the arrays to encode in a netCDF file.

foreword.p: This encoding is intended to provide a faster and more compact alternative to the Moving Features CSV encoding using a format readable by existing software.

clause.title: IV.Security considerations
clause.p: No security considerations have been made for this document.

clause.title: V.Submitting Organizations
clause.p: The following organizations submitted this Document to the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC):

submitters.title: VI.Submitters
submitters.p: All questions regarding this submission should be directed to the editor or the submitters:

clause.title: VII.Reference notes
clause.p: The OGC 11-165r2 CF-netCDF standard is based on Climate and Forecast (CF) conventions version 1.6. The Attribute Convention for Data Discovery (ACDD) adds additional attributes that provide useful metadata for Catalog Service on the Web (CSW). The National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI) document is used as a guideline when an ambiguity needs to be resolved.

This document references OGC 11-165r2 when possible, but the on-line CF, ACDD, or NCEI documents may be referenced when additional information is considered relevant to moving feature binary encoding.

clause.title: 1.Scope
clause.p: This OGC® Best Practice gives guidelines for encoding in netCDF files the geometries of features that move as rigid bodies. This is an alternative to the encoding defined by the OGC Moving Features Encoding Extension: Simple Comma Separated Values (CSV) standard. netCDF encoding can store moving features with the following characteristics:

li.p: Each moving feature can be described with the Schema for Moving Features (ISO 19141:2008);
The number of features simultaneously encoded with this format can be massive (many thousands of features);
All features can be described using common space-time coordinates;
Trajectories are described by a single point (not a line string) at each time step;
Foliation order is sequential, i.e., trajectory elements that are parts of one track are ordered by time.

clause.p: Deforming features such as floodwater and geometric complexes are out of scope.

This OGC document describes relevant attributes from the Climate and Forecast (CF) conventions in sufficient detail that client applications do not need to deal with the entire scope of CF conventions. Applications only need to understand a restricted subset of CF conventions in order to be able to interpret moving features in netCDF files.

clause.title: 2.Conformance
clause.p: Conformance with this specification shall be checked using all the relevant tests specified in Annex A (normative).

terms.title: 4.Terms and definitions
terms.p: This document uses the terms defined in OGC Policy Directive 49, which is based on the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2, Rules for the structure and drafting of International Standards. In particular, the word “shall” (not “must”) is the verb form used to indicate a requirement to be strictly followed to conform to this document and OGC documents do not use the equivalent phrases in the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2.

This document also uses terms defined in the OGC Standard for Modular specifications (OGC 08-131r3), also known as the ‘ModSpec’. The definitions of terms such as standard, specification, requirement, and conformance test are provided in the ModSpec.
For the purposes of this document, the following additional terms and definitions apply.

This document uses the terms defined in Sub-clause 5.3 of OGC 06-121r8, which is based on the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2, Rules for the structure and drafting of International Standards. In particular, the word “shall” (not “must”) is the verb form used to indicate a requirement to be strictly followed to conform to this standard.

definition.p: Representation, using a local origin and local ordinate vectors, of a geometric object at a given reference time.
Quantity having direction as well as magnitude.
Spatial object representing a geometric set.
Geometric object representing a single, connected, homogeneous element of space.
1-dimensional geometric primitive representing extent in time.
0-dimensional geometric primitive representing a position in time.
Path of a moving point described by a one parameter set of points.
One parameter set of geometries such that each point in the prism of the set is in one and only one trajectory and in one and only one leaf.

Function
f

t ∈
[ a , b

f
( t )
f(t) is a geometry and for each point
P ∈ f

P in f(a) there is a one parameter set of points (called the trajectory of
P

Set of points in the union of the geometries (or the union of the trajectories) of a one parameter set of geometries.
Geometry at a particular value of the parameter.
NetCDF attributes hold metadata. An attribute contains information about properties of a variable or an entire dataset.
Global attributes apply to a whole dataset and may be used to record properties of all the data in a file, such as processing history or conventions used.
Variable attributes record the properties of one variable.

A netCDF variable has a name, type, shape, attributes, and values. In face, much of the netCDF specification consists of defining the specific characteristics of variables. Variables hold data values. In the netCDF model, a variable can hold a multidimensional array of values of the same type.
The shape of a variable is specified with a list of zero or more dimensions.
NetCDF dimensions are used to specify variable shapes, common grids, and coordinate systems.

clause.title: 6.Conventions
clause.p: This section provides details and examples for conventions used in the document.

definitions.title: 6.1.Abbreviated terms
definitions.p: The following symbols and abbreviated terms are used in this Best Practice:

dd.p: International Association of Oil & Gas producers
NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information

clause.title: 7.Data model
clause.p:
The data model used by the binary encoding is equivalent to that used by the CSV encoding. Figure 1 shows an example for trajectories of three moving points
A
A,
B
B and
C
C. Each trajectory has the same start time and the same end time.

li.p:
At
t = 0
t = 0 (start of all data), all points start moving.

At
t = 1
t = 1, the movement of
A
A is changed.

At
t = 2
t = 2 (end of all data), the movement of
A
A,
B
B and
C
C are changed.

clause.p:
In the case, the trajectory of
A
A from
t = 0
t = 0 to
t = 1
t = 1 and from
t = 1
t = 1 to
t = 2
t = 2 is encoded, together with the trajectories of
B
B and
C
C from
t = 0
t = 0 to
t = 2
t = 2.

clause.title: 8.Data structure and file format
clause.p: The binary encoding of arrays and attributes is defined by OGC 10-092r3 – NetCDF Binary Encoding Extension Standard: netCDF Classic and 64-bit Offset Format. That netCDF standard defines only a “container” format – it does not define the meaning of attributes stored in the file (the “schema” in XML terminology).
The full content of OGC 10-092r3 standard is needed for Moving Feature Simple Binary; this Best Practice does not propose any addition or subset of OGC 10-092r3.

tr.td: All Moving Features binary files shall be compliant with the netCDF binary encoding as specified by the OGC 10-092r3 standard.

clause.p: Meanings of attributes in a netCDF file are defined by a separated standard, OGC 11-165r2 – CF-netCDF3 Data Model Extension. All remaining requirements and recommendations in this Moving Feature Simple Binary document apply to a subset of those CF conventions.

clause.title: 8.1.NetCDF global attributes
clause.p: Global attributes apply to the netCDF file as a whole. They specify a succinct description of what is in the dataset, the kind of sampling geometry, the geographic bounding box, the vertical extent, the time period, the coordinate reference systems used and many other metadata (see CF convention). Some global attributes are merely a convenience for information that may otherwise be tedious to compute; those attributes are presented in Clause 8.1.2.

clause.title: 8.1.1.Non-redundant global attributes
clause.p: This sub-section presents some global attributes that do not duplicate information provided by other attributes.

clause.title: 8.1.1.1.Identification of conventions
clause.p: To identify that the file uses the CF convention, OGC 11-162r2 §7.3.2.1 requires that the Conventions global attribute is set to the "CF-1.6" string value. This Best Practice uses also some attribute convention for data discovery, which is notified by the "ACDD-1.3" string value.

tr.td: The file shall define the global attribute Conventions to a string of comma-separated values containing at least the "CF-1.6" element. The list of values should contain also the "ACDD-1.3" element. A complete string value containing the two elements is "CF-1.6, ACDD-1.3".

clause.title: 8.1.1.2.Feature type
clause.p: The CF conventions allow different kinds of sampling geometry such as point, time series, profile, or trajectory. This binary encoding Best Practice focuses on trajectories. This choice constraint the data layout to a series of data points along a path through space with monotonically increasing times (OGC 11-165r2 §7.5.2.3).

tr.td: The file shall define the global attribute featureType to the string value "trajectory".

clause.title: 8.1.1.3.Title
clause.p: Both CF convention and ACDD recommend the inclusion of a title in the global attributes.

tr.td: The file should define the global attribute title to a succinct description of what is in the dataset.

clause.title: 8.1.2.Convenience global attributes for data discovery
clause.p: This sub-section presents global attributes that duplicate information available in other attributes, but in a more convenient manner. For example, the geographic bounding box attributes (Clause 8.1.2.1) duplicate information provided by the geospatial bounds attributes (Clause 8.1.2.2 to Clause 8.1.2.4), but may avoid the need to apply an inverse map projection. The geospatial bounds attributes themselves duplicate attributes associated to coordinate variables. But the attributes described in this sub-section make it easier to discover the data. Indeed, all attributes in this sub-section come from the Attribute Convention for Data Discovery (ACDD). By contrast, most attributes in other sections come from the Climate and Forecast (CF) convention.

clause.title: 8.1.2.1.Geographic bounding box
clause.p: The geographic bounding box is given in longitude and latitude regardless of the Coordinate Reference System (CRS) used by the trajectories. Since those metadata are used for discovery purpose only, the geodetic datum is unspecified. Coordinate precision may be of only two decimal places of a degree.

td.p: The file should define the following global attributes:

Respective values are the southernmost and northernmost latitudes, followed by the easternmost and westernmost longitudes covered by the dataset. Units of measurement should be degrees with positive latitudes in the North hemisphere and longitude values increasing toward east. The “minimal” longitude may be greater than the “maximal” longitude if the bounding box crosses the discontinuity meridian. The Prime Meridian should be Greenwich. Values type should be floating point.

clause.p: This geographic bounding box is redundant with the geospatial bounds defined below. The geographic bounding box is optional metadata for easier discovery of a dataset without the need to parse Well Known Text, lookup EPSG codes, and reproject envelopes.

clause.title: 8.1.2.2.Geospatial (not necessarily geographic) bounds
clause.p: The horizontal part of the spatial boundary of moving features is specified as geometry in Well Known Text (WKT) format. The Coordinate Reference System is specified in Clause 8.1.2.5.

This metadata is equivalent to the mf:STBoundedBy element defined by Moving Features Core and to the @stboundedby element defined by the CSV extension, except that the geometry is not an envelope (but may be an equivalent polygon) and does not contain vertical or temporal components.

tr.td: The file should define the global attribute geospatial_bounds to a Well Known Text (WKT) that specifies the horizontal part of a geometry encompassing all moving features in the dataset. The geometry may be a polygon. Meaning and order of values for each point’s coordinates depend on the Coordinate Reference System (Clause 8.1.2.5).

clause.title: 8.1.2.3.Vertical bounds
clause.p: If the feature trajectories are three-dimensional, then the vertical part of the spatial boundary of moving features is specified as a range of floating-point values. The Coordinate Reference System is specified in Clause 8.1.2.5.
This metadata is equivalent to the vertical component of mf:STBoundedBy (Moving Features Core) or @stboundedby (CSV extension).

tr.td: If the moving features feature trajectories are three-dimensional, then the file should define the global attribute geospatial_vertical_min and geospatial_vertical_max to the numerically smaller and larger vertical limit, respectively. Values type should be floating point. Meaning of values depends on the Coordinate Reference System (Clause 8.1.2.5).

clause.title: 8.1.2.4.Temporal bounds
clause.p: The times of the first and last data point in the file are specified as a range of dates. Dates are formatted as specified by ISO 8601:2004, preferably the extended date-time format (YYYY-MM-DD T hh:mm:ss optionally followed by the time zone).

tr.td: The file should define the global attribute time_coverage_start to the time of the first data point, and time_coverage_end to the time of the last data point. Dates are encoded as strings in ISO 8701:2004 format.

clause.title: 8.1.2.5.Spatial Reference System
clause.p: The Coordinate Reference System (CRS) of the geospatial and vertical bounds (Clause 8.1.2.2 and Clause 8.1.2.3) is specified by an authority code, preferably from the EPSG geodetic dataset. For two-dimensional trajectories, only one CRS should be specified. For three-dimensional trajectories, a single three-dimensional CRS or two distinct CRS (one horizontal and one vertical) may be specified depending on the nature of the vertical heights.

While ACDD uses simple strings of the form "EPSG:4326", this document recommends URNs of the form "urn:ogc:def:crs:EPSG::4326" instead. However, software should be prepared to read both forms. Note that axis order is the same with both forms, namely (latitude, longitude) in EPSG:4326 case.
This metadata is equivalent to the srsName attribute in Moving Feature core and to the srid attribute in CSV extension, except for the possible separation between a horizontal and a vertical CRS.

td.p: The file should define the global attribute geospatial_bounds_crs and may define the global attribute geospatial_bounds_vertical_crs to authority codes (preferable from the EPSG geodetic dataset) determined according the following choices:

li.p: If the trajectories are three-dimensional and horizontal coordinates are geodetic (geographic or geocentric) latitudes and longitudes and the vertical coordinates are heights above the ellipsoid, then:
geospatial_bounds_vertical_crs attribute is not present.

geospatial_bounds_crs is the authority code of a single three-dimensional geodetic CRS used by both geospatial_bounds (for the horizontal part) and by geospatial_vertical_min and geospatial_vertical_max (for the vertical part) attribute values. For example EPSG:4979 is the three-dimensional variant of EPSG:4326.
Otherwise:
geospatial_bounds_crs is the authority code of the two-dimensional CRS used by the geospatial_bounds attribute value.
geospatial_bounds_vertical_crs is the authority code of the CRS used by geospatial_vertical_min and geospatial_vertical_max, if present.

clause.title: 8.2.Trajectory lines (data body)
clause.p: The CF convention proposes four different ways to organize the feature coordinates and attributes in a netCDF file. This best-practice paper chooses the Contiguous Ragged Array representation, which has the following characteristics:

li.p: Can mix short and large features without waste of space;
Number of points of each feature must be known in advance;
File can be updated with new features or new points in the last feature (but not new points in previous features); and
Foliation order is restricted to “sequential”.

clause.p: The file is organized by first defining netCDF dimensions (not to be confused with spatio-temporal dimensions), then variables. The dimension and variable names shall comply with the restrictions documented in OGC 11-162r2 §7.3.2.1:

td.p: NetCDF dimension names and netCDF variable names shall comply with the following restrictions:

li.p: Names shall begin with a letter;
Names shall be composed of letters, digits or underscores; and
No variable has the same name than a dimension, except the variable holding feature identifiers (Clause 8.2.2.1).

clause.title: 8.2.1.NetCDF dimensions
clause.p: The ragged array representation needs three netCDF dimensions, described below.

clause.title: 8.2.1.1.Maximal length of feature identifiers
clause.p: If each feature is identified by a string value, then the netCDF file needs to declare the maximal number of characters allowed in those identifiers. Identifiers shorter than the maximal length will be padded by spaces of null characters (readers must be prepared to handle both).

tr.td: If features are identified by string values, then the file shall define a netCDF dimension for identifier characters (the identifier char dimension). The name of this dimension can be any name compliant with the requirements in Clause 8.2. The length of this dimension is the maximum number of characters than can be stored in a feature identifier.

clause.title: 8.2.1.2.Feature instance dimension
clause.p: The netCDF file shall declare a dimension for information about each feature as a whole (i.e., information that does not depend on the time). The length of this dimension is the maximal number of features that can be stored in the file. It is acceptable to declare a length larger than needed in order to reserve room for future feature additions, provided that values in the count variable (Clause 8.2.2.2) are set to zero for all missing features.

tr.td: The file shall define a netCDF dimension for feature instances (the instance dimension). The name of this dimension can be any name compliant with the requirements in Clause 8.2. The length of this dimension is the maximum number of features that can be stored in the file.

clause.title: 8.2.1.3.Sample dimension
clause.p: The netCF file shall declare a dimension for the actual data (time, geospatial coordinates and feature attributes). This dimension could have a fixed length, but it is more convenient to declare this dimension length as unlimited if new data need to be appended. Note that a netCDF file can have only one dimension of unlimited length.

tr.td: The file shall define a netCDF dimension for time-dependent data (the sample dimension). The name of this dimension can be any name compliant with the requirements in Clause 8.2. The length of this dimension should be unlimited, unless the total number of points is known in advance.

clause.title: 8.2.2.NetCDF variables
clause.p: In the continuous ragged array representation, the netCDF file shall contain the following variables:

li.p: One variable listing feature identifiers;
One variable counting the number of points in each feature;

Three or four auxiliary coordinate variables (not to be confused with “simple” coordinate variables): examples:
x
x,
y
y, (
z
z) and
t
t; and
An arbitrary number of variables for feature attributes (not to be confused with global attributes or variable attributes): examples: state, temperature.

clause.title: 8.2.2.1.Feature identifiers
clause.p: Each trajectory should have identifying text that specifies the moving feature. The text can be a person ID, a vehicle ID, etc. While the identifier is usually a string, integer types are also allowed.
The data stored in this variable are equivalent to the mfIdRef attribute value in Moving Feature XML file, or to the values in the mfidref column in a Moving Feature CSV file.

td.p: The file shall define a variable holding the identifier of each trajectory.

li.p: The variable name shall be identical to the name of the instance dimension defined in Clause 8.2.1.2.
The variable type should be the character type. Integer types are also valid.

The variable dimension shall be the instance dimension (Clause 8.2.1.2) and the identifier char dimension (Clause 8.2.1.1), in that order. The char dimension shall be omitted if the variable type is not a character type.
The collection of variable attributes shall contain:
A cf_role attribute set to the "trajectory_id" string value.

clause.title: 8.2.2.2.Count variable
clause.p: The netCDF file shall contain a variable holding the number of points in each trajectory. The length of this variable is the maximum number of features that the netCDF file can contain.

td.p: The file shall define a variable holding the count of the number of points in each trajectory (the count variable).

li.p: The variable name can be any name compliant with the requirements in Clause 8.2.
The variable type shall be an integer.
The variable dimension shall be the instance dimension defined in Clause 8.2.1.2.
The collection of variable attributes shall contain:
A sample_dimension attribute set to the name of the sample dimension defined in Clause 8.2.1.3.

clause.title: 8.2.2.3.Auxiliary coordinate variables
clause.p: Trajectory coordinates are specified in one variable for each spatiotemporal dimension. Those “auxiliary coordinate variables” are not subject to the usual restrictions of netCDF “coordinate variables”. In particular:

li.p: The variable name does not match the dimension name;
The values do not need to be ordered monotonically;
The variable does not have axis attribute; and
The variable may have missing values.

clause.p: Ordinate values of the first feature – i.e., the feature at index 0 in the feature instance dimension (Clause 8.2.1.2) – are written first. The number of values to write for that first feature is given by the value of the count variable (Clause 8.2.2.2) at index 0. Then the ordinate values of the second feature – i.e., the feature at index 1 in the feature instance dimension – follow. The number of values to write for that second feature is given by the value of the count variable at index 1, and so on.
For example, if a file contains three features identified as “A”, “B” and “C” and if their trajectories are described by the following points:

li.p: A: start at (11, 2) then move to (12, 3) and finally (10, 3);
B: start at (10, 2) then move to (11, 3); and
C: start at (12, 1) then move to (10, 2) and finally (11, 3).

clause.p: Then the feature instance dimension has a length of 3 and the sample dimension (if not unlimited) has a length of 3 + 2 + 3 = 8. In such cases the variables presented in previous sub-sections have the following values:
NetCDF variables having the feature instance dimension (Clause 8.2.1.2):
The auxiliary coordinate variables can be as below:
NetCDF variables having the sample dimension (Clause 8.2.1.3):

td.p: The file shall contain three or four auxiliary coordinate variables.

li.p: The variable name can be any name compliant with the requirements in Clause 8.2.
The variable type shall be a numerical type (usually floating point).
The variable dimension shall be the sample dimension defined in Clause 8.1.2.3.
The collection of attributes of the time coordinates variable shall contain:
A standard_name attribute set to the "time" string value.
A units attribute set to the “units since YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss” string value where:
“units” can be “days”, “hours”, “minutes” or “seconds”,
“YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss” is the epoch in UTC.
The collection of attributes of spatial coordinates variables shall contain:
A standard_name attribute if and only if a standard name exists in the CF Standard Name Table ( ) for that variable. Examples of standard names are "longitude", "latitude" and "altitude".
A units attribute. Examples are "degrees_east", "degrees_north" and "km".
The collection of attributes of all coordinates variable shall contain:
An axis attribute with one of the following names: "X", "Y", "Z" or "T".

clause.p: In addition to the attributes listed in above requirement, some non-standards attributes may help parsers to identify the coordinate system. In particular, the _CoordinateAxisType attribute may be set to "Lon", "Lat", "Height" or "Time" values for a geographic CRS, or to the "GeoX", "GeoY", "GeoZ" or "Time" values for other kind of CRS.

clause.title: 8.2.2.4.Feature attribute variables
clause.p: If the file contains additional attributes for the moving features, they can be declared in array having the same length than the auxiliary coordinate variables. Elements in those variables are mapped to features and time in the same way than the values in auxiliary coordinate variables (Clause 8.2.2.3).

tr.td:
If the file contains additional feature attributes, then those values shall be stored in one distinct variable for each feature attribute. The dimension of those variables is the sample dimension. Values at index
i
i are associated to the same feature at the same time than the values of auxiliary coordinate variables at index
i
i.

clause.p: OGC 11-162r2 has additional requirements for the exchange of scientific data.

tr.td: If the variable represents one of the physical quantities for which a standard name exists in the CF Standard Name Table ( ), then the variable shall define a standard_name attribute to the string value given in that table. Otherwise the variable shall define a long_name attribute to a long descriptive name that may, for example, be used for labeling plots.

If the variable represents a dimensional quantity, then it shall define a units attribute to a string value that can be recognized by UNIDATA’s udunits package, with the addition of "level", "layer" and "sigma_level" string values. That unit shall be consistent with the unit given in the CF Standard Name Table for the standard_name attribute value, if the later attribute exists for this variable.

clause.title: 8.2.2.5.Feature attribute variables as character strings
clause.p: If the values of a feature attribute variable are character strings, then there is a choice:

li.p: If only a limited amount of distinct values are used (e.g., values are members of an enumeration), then those values can be encoded as flags as described in CF conventions §3.5 (details below);

Otherwise a new dimension need to be defined with a length equal to the maximal number of characters to be stored in the feature attribute variable. This dimension is added as the last dimensions of the feature attribute variable, as defined in CF-convention §2.2. This dimension is shown as the “character dimension” in the figure below.

clause.p: The second approach may result in a netCDF file as big as or bigger than an equivalent CSV file since all character strings shorter than the maximal length are padded with spaces or zero values. For efficiency reasons, this paper recommends the use of flags.

td.p: Feature attribute variables of type character strings should be encoded as flags if the amount of distinct values is reasonably small.

li.p: Variable type should be byte or short.
The collection of variable attributes should contain:
A flag_values attribute of the same type (byte or short) than the variable. The attribute value is the list of distinct numerical values that can appear in the variable.

A flag_meanings attribute of the type string. The attribute value is a space-separated list of tokens (a token is a word or a phrase in which space characters have been replaced by underscore characters). The first token is the string representation of the first numerical value listed in the flag_values array, the second token is the string representation of the second numerical value listed in the flag_values array, etc.

references.title: 3.Normative references
references.p: The following documents are referred to in the text in such a way that some or all of their content constitutes requirements of this document. For dated references, only the edition cited applies. For undated references, the latest edition of the referenced document (including any amendments) applies.

bibitem.formattedref: Akinori Asahara, Ryosuke Shibasaki, Nobuhiro Ishimaru, David Burggraf: OGC 14-083r2, OGC® Moving Features Encoding Part I: XML Core. Open Geospatial Consortium (2015). http://www.opengis.net/doc/IS/movingfeatures/xmlcore/1.0.0.

Akinori Asahara, Ryosuke Shibasaki, Nobuhiro Ishimaru, David Burggraf: OGC 14-084r2, OGC® Moving Features Encoding Extension: Simple Comma Separated Values (CSV). Open Geospatial Consortium (2015). http://www.opengis.net/doc/IS/movingfeatures/csv-extension/1.0.0.
Ben Domenico: OGC 10-090r3, OGC Network Common Data Form (NetCDF) Core Encoding Standard version 1.0. Open Geospatial Consortium (2011).
Ben Domenico: OGC 10-092r3, NetCDF Binary Encoding Extension Standard: NetCDF Classic and 64-bit Offset Format. Open Geospatial Consortium (2011).
Ben Domenico and Stefano Nativi: OGC 11-165r2, CF-netCDF3 Data Model Extension standard. Open Geospatial Consortium (2013). http://www.opengis.net/doc/is/netcdf-data-model-extension/1.0.0.
ISO: ISO 19101-1:2014, Geographic information — Reference model — Part 1: Fundamentals. International Organization for Standardization, Geneva (2014). https://www.iso.org/standard/59164.html.
ISO: ISO 19141:2008, Geographic information — Schema for moving features. International Organization for Standardization, Geneva (2008). https://www.iso.org/standard/41445.html.
ISO: ISO 19107:2003, Geographic information — Spatial schema. International Organization for Standardization, Geneva (2003). https://www.iso.org/standard/26012.html.
ISO: ISO 19123:2005, Geographic information — Schema for coverage geometry and functions. International Organization for Standardization, Geneva (2005). https://www.iso.org/standard/40121.html.
Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory: NetCDF CF Metadata Conventions.
ESIP: Attribute Convention for Data Discovery (ACDD).

annex.title:
Annex A
(normative)
Conformance test
annex.p: Moving Features encoded in a netCDF file may be tested with the UCAR library, for example using the Java code below (replace “myFile.nc” and “myAttribute” by character strings applicable to the data to be tested). As of version 4.6.4 of UCAR netCDF library, this test requires the non-standard _CoordinateAxisType attribute on the auxiliary coordinate variables (see the note after requirement 10). For that reason, this test is non-normative.
